body: or else we decide that `self.N` now stands for `N_padded`, i.e., the length of the signal after padding = the length of the filters at the full resolution. This would actually be most consistent with the 3D module. But that implies to rename fields in the 2D module: `N_padded` becomes `N`, `M_padded` becomes `M`.
I'd be in favor of removing. We could argue that these were intended to be private attributes and users shouldn't rely on them. Safe thing would be to issue a deprecation warning, however.

> We could argue that these were intended to be private attributes

@janden i came to the same conclusion. 


>  Safe thing would be to issue a deprecation warning, however.

i can do that !

issue.title: MAINT deprecate `self.N` and `self.J_pad` in 1D

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body:
Fixes #857 

An important deprecation to set before we release v0.3 is `J_pad`. Indeed, there won't be a `J_pad_fr` in JTFS, so it'd best to plan for symmetry in design.

```python
_N_padded, _N_padded_fr
J, J_fr
Q, Q_fr
T, F
log2_T, log2_F
```

I have moved the shape check to its own static method. We'll be able to call this method a second time inside `self._check_input(x)` (recently merged!)

body: @eickenberg Your call on this API-breaking change.

this PR is related to JTFS. Here's my rationale:
* i'd like to avoid having to write a `jtfs_filter_factory`
* rather, i'd like to call `scattering_filter_factory` twice: once for the temporal filters and again (with different arguments) for the frequential filters
* but i don't want to have to assume that the input  of the frequential scattering has a power-of-two support. That would require a lot of padding (up to ~JQ zeros, i.e. >100) and thus woul hurt speed and memory usage. Rather i'd like to pad to a non-power-of-two multiple of 2**log2_F (aka the frequential "stride" )
* yet `scattering_filter_factory` currently takes `J_pad` (the log2 of the padded support) as input. Since J_pad must be integer, it follows that the padded input must be a power of two in length.
* so i will propose (in a separate PR) that `scattering_filter_factory` should take N_padded, not J_pad, as input.
* that future PR will improve consistency with Scattering2D, whose `scattering_filter_factory` requires takes `N_padded`, not its log2, as input.
* besides JTFS, that future PR will also benefit 1D (aka "plain time scattering") because it will speed up the code (smaller input) and reduce memory usage (better data/padding ratio).
* of course this PR will require its own test suite and careful review
* but for now, i think it is clear that J_pad is not necessary to instantiate the 1D scattering filter factory, so i propose to do it now (in 0.3) with the plan of removing it in 0.4.
* The removal will be justified by a concern of "principle of minimum surprise" between time scattering parameters (N,J,Q,T) and frequency scattering (N_fr, J_fr, Q_fr, T_fr). There won't be an integer named J_pad_fr
* in conclusion, i believe that this deprecation / API change is a reasonable price to pay in front of improved consistency and flexibility

@eickenberg i hope this clarifies

So you're saying that we should allow the filters to have non-power-of-two sizes? Then yes, I agree with that. The filters are technically part of the public API, but still in a sort of grey zone (I don't believe they're documented). So I don't think it's too much of an issue to break it.
But why even keep the `N` attribute? The padded size is, in a sense, an internal parameter for the implementation. Why do we need to expose it to the user at all?
I think that sounds like a good idea.
Might be good to rename it to something like `_N_padded`, though to make clear it's the padded size that's intended.

issue.title: `self.M`, `self.N` should be deprecated in 1D and 2D

repository.name: kymatio

issue.body:
for consistency with 1D #857
we should rename `self.M_padded` and `self.N_padded` to `self._M_padded` and `self._N_padded`

~~same for 3D, `self._O_padded` etc.~~
